messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 62 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Testing and learning structured quantum Hamiltonians

Paper Abstract: Abstract We consider the problems of testing and learning an n𝑛n-qubit Hamiltonian H=∑xλx​σx𝐻subscript𝑥subscript𝜆𝑥subscript𝜎𝑥H=\sum_{x}\lambda_{x}\sigma_{x} expressed in its Pauli basis, from queries to its evolution operator U=e−i​H​t𝑈superscript𝑒𝑖𝐻𝑡U=e^{-iHt} with respect the normalized Frobenius norm. To this end, we prove the following results (with and without quantum memory) for Hamiltonians whose Pauli spectrum involves only k𝑘k-local terms or has sparsity at most s𝑠s: 1. Local Hamiltonians: We give a tolerant testing protocol to decide if a Hamiltonian is ε1subscript𝜀1\varepsilon_{1}-close to k𝑘k-local or ε2subscript𝜀2\varepsilon_{2}-far from k𝑘k-local, with O​(1/(ε2−ε1)4)𝑂1superscriptsubscript𝜀2subscript𝜀14O(1/(\varepsilon_{2}-\varepsilon_{1})^{4}) queries, thereby solving two open questions posed in a recent work by Bluhm, Caro and Oufkir [5]. For learning a k𝑘k-local Hamiltonian up to error ε𝜀\varepsilon, we give a protocol with query complexity and total time evolution exp⁡(O​(k2+k​log⁡(1/ε)))𝑂superscript𝑘2𝑘1𝜀\exp(O(k^{2}+k\log(1/\varepsilon))). Our algorithm leverages the non-commutative Bohnenblust-Hille inequality in order to get a complexity independent of n𝑛n. 2. Sparse Hamiltonians: We give a protocol for testing whether a Hamiltonian is ε1subscript𝜀1\varepsilon_{1}-close to being s𝑠s-sparse or ε2subscript𝜀2\varepsilon_{2}-far from being s𝑠s-sparse, with O​(s6/(ε22−ε12)6)𝑂superscript𝑠6superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜀22superscriptsubscript𝜀126O(s^{6}/(\varepsilon_{2}^{2}-\varepsilon_{1}^{2})^{6}) queries. For learning up to error ε𝜀\varepsilon, we show that O​(s4/ε8)𝑂superscript𝑠4superscript𝜀8O(s^{4}/\varepsilon^{8}) queries suffices. 3. Learning without quantum memory: The learning results stated above have no dependence on the system size n𝑛n, but require n𝑛n-qubit quantum memory. We give subroutines that allow us to reproduce all the above learning results without quantum memory; increasing the query complexity by a (log⁡n)𝑛(\log n)-factor in the local case and an n𝑛n-factor in the sparse case. 4. Testing without quantum memory: We give a new subroutine called Pauli hashing, which allows one to tolerantly test s𝑠s-sparse Hamiltonians using O~​(s14/(ε22−ε12)18)~𝑂superscript𝑠14superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜀22superscriptsubscript𝜀1218\tilde{O}(s^{14}/(\varepsilon_{2}^{2}-\varepsilon_{1}^{2})^{18}) query complexity. A key ingredient is showing that s𝑠s-sparse Pauli channels can be tested in a tolerant fashion as being ε1subscript𝜀1\varepsilon_{1}-close to being s𝑠s-sparse or ε2subscript𝜀2\varepsilon_{2}-far under the diamond norm, using O~​(s2/(ε2−ε1)6)~𝑂superscript𝑠2superscriptsubscript𝜀2subscript𝜀16\tilde{O}(s^{2}/(\varepsilon_{2}-\varepsilon_{1})^{6}) queries via Pauli hashing. In order to prove these results, we prove new structural theorems for local Hamiltonians, sparse Pauli channels and sparse Hamiltonians. We complement our learning algorithms with lower bounds that are polynomially weaker. Furthermore, our algorithms use short time evolutions and do not assume prior knowledge of the terms on which the Pauli spectrum is supported on, i.e., we do not require prior knowledge about the support of the Hamiltonian terms.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 62 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 62"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Sample-efficient learning of interacting quantum systems",
        "Quantum algorithmic measurement",
        "Optimal quantum sample complexity of learning algorithms",
        "A new proof for the existence of mutually unbiased bases",
        "Hamiltonian property testing (version 1)",
        "Hamiltonian property testing (version 2)",
        "Testing juntas nearly optimally",
        "Learning quantum hamiltonians at any temperature in polynomial time",
        "Structure learning of hamiltonians from real-time evolution",
        "Techniques for learning sparse Pauli-Lindblad noise models",
        "A short note on learning discrete distributions",
        "Learning quantum processes and hamiltonians via the pauli transfer matrix",
        "Constructing smaller pauli twirling sets for arbitrary error channels",
        "Exponential separations between learning with and without quantum memory",
        "Efficient Pauli channel estimation with logarithmic quantum memory",
        "Optimal tradeoffs for estimating pauli observables",
        "An optimal tradeoff between entanglement and copy complexity for state tomography",
        "Testing and Learning Quantum Juntas Nearly Optimally",
        "Hamiltonian learning via shadow tomography of pseudo-choi states",
        "Quantum advantages for pauli channel estimation",
        "The advantage of quantum control in many-body hamiltonian learning",
        "Active learning of quantum system Hamiltonians yields query advantage",
        "Practical characterization of quantum devices without tomography",
        "Low-degree learning and the metric entropy of polynomials",
        "Lower bounds on learning pauli channels",
        "Efficient estimation of Pauli channels",
        "Optimizing quantum optimization algorithms via faster quantum gradient computation",
        "Practical hamiltonian learning with unitary dynamics and gibbs states",
        "Robust online Hamiltonian learning",
        "Property testing and its connection to learning and approximation",
        "Testing Fourier dimensionality and sparsity",
        "Simple algorithms to test and learn local hamiltonians",
        "On the representation of boolean and real functions as hamiltonians for quantum computing",
        "Scalable reconstruction of unitary processes and hamiltonians",
        "Learning to predict arbitrary quantum processes",
        "Optimal learning of quantum hamiltonians from high-temperature gibbs states",
        "The list-decoding size of fourier-sparse boolean functions",
        "Learning many-body hamiltonians with heisenberg-limited scaling",
        "Supervised learning of time-independent Hamiltonians for gate design",
        "Heisenberg-limited hamiltonian learning for interacting bosons",
        "Quantum algorithms for testing hamiltonian symmetry",
        "Dissipation-enabled bosonic hamiltonian learning via new information-propagation bounds",
        "Characterizing quantum gates via randomized benchmarking",
        "Quantum boolean functions",
        "Optimal lower bounds for quantum automata and random access codes",
        "Learning sparse boolean polynomials",
        "Analysis of Boolean Functions",
        "Efficient learning of ground & thermal states within phases of matter",
        "Quantum computing in the nisq era and beyond",
        "Approximating the distance to monotonicity of boolean functions",
        "Learning quantum many-body systems from a few copies",
        "Efficient and robust estimation of many-qubit hamiltonians",
        "Procedure for systematically tuning up cross-talk in the cross-resonance gate",
        "Unitary Property Testing Lower Bounds by Polynomials",
        "Topics in random matrix theory, volume 132",
        "Noncommutative Bohnenblust–Hille inequalities",
        "Property testing of unitary operators",
        "Scalably learning quantum many-body hamiltonians from dynamical data",
        "Robust and efficient hamiltonian learning",
        "Sample Efficient Identity Testing and Independence Testing of Quantum States",
        "Fast Fourier Sparsity Testing",
        "Optimal short-time measurements for hamiltonian learning"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 62 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Testing and learning structured quantum Hamiltonians, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
